Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2012 05:31PM hwhranch wrote: You have the same type of breast cancer that 80% of women get, that's what my doctor told me when he called with the results of the biopsy. I said well then you should have no trouble treating it right? Your cancer is very favorable for treatment and the fact that you are hormone receptor positive gives the doctor another avenue of treatment to help. It's easy to get wrapped up in the fear of it all but I'm telling you the best thing you can do is keep moving forward and stay positive because this to shall pass. It will be a bump in the road of your long life!!!!
Posts.Title: Diagnosis very hard to handle neugirl Appetite4life

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 12:20PM hwhranch wrote: i finished chemo June 2011 and I had a full head of really short short hair by the time I started Radiation in September.  By the end of summer I was going hat and scarfless.  I did not do wigs because in Texas it's to hot, lol.  I wore caps and scarves the whole time.  I  had lost all eyebrows and lashes and all the hair on my arms, legs and you know where.  It was January before the leg hair came back, that was a bummer.  I did not have to shave all summer of 2011.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2013 12:23PM hwhranch wrote: perfectly normal...they may also request a bone scan and a PET scan just to cover all bases.  These are all tools that help them gather the most information so they can design the best treatment plan for you.
Posts.Title: Bilateral Breast MRI BabsBennett jacee

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 02:07PM hwhranch wrote: I just kept mine really short during that curly stage.  Drove me nuts but in June, 1 year after chemo my hair went straight again, it was almost overnight, lol.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2012 08:34AM hwhranch wrote: I just wanted to say that I had a needle biopsy done on my lymph node the same time as my breast tumor.  My breast tumor was over 5c and the lymph node was swolen.  But it was the only one that was cancerous...I think they removed 15 and only the one showed cancer....and mine had not spread anywhere.  It's really hard but you just need to wait till you get that diagnoses so you know what you are dealing with.  Since my tumor was so big I had to undergo chemo before any surgeries.  We shrank that sucker big time but I still had to have a mx because there were 3 small islands on the outer edges of where the tumor was...and it was kind of horse shoe shaped.  Deep breath and try to stay positive and move forward.  Once all the tests and dr's visits and treatments start you will be one busy woman killing this cancer.
Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2012 07:16PM hwhranch wrote: I had 4 AC treatments followed by 4 taxol treatments on a 3rd generation regime. That meant every two weeks. Hair fell out after 2nd treatment, lost it all but it started coming back about 3 months after treatments were over. The Nulasta shots didn't really hurt me, very small needle but I would get extremely sore from the bone pain the 2-3 days after the shot.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo November 2012 michellej1980 IamNancy

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2013 11:29AM hwhranch wrote: Those of you having problems with taste....that's just how it is.  Don't feel alone at all. My husband was buying me everything under the sun to try to find something for me to eat. It changed from week to week...sometimes it was mashed potatoes, some times it was a chicken pot pie, most of the time it was nothing.  That Red Devil crap just trashes your taste buds.  What ever it is you can eat, just eat that and don't worry about what it is.  Experience talking here.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo November 2012 michellej1980 IamNancy

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 01:42PM hwhranch wrote: polotici...don't worry.  I was having 4 of the red devil coctail every two weeks and not every 3.  Just when I would get back up it seems I would get knocked down again.  It made me so sick during the infusion that I would have to be knocked out and given phenegren...which gave me bad leg shakes.  Needless to say I had a couple of big melt downs, lol.  Once my nurse navigator called to check on me and I totally came unhinged on her.  Crying and really having a huge pitty party, I felt much better when it was over.  The point being no matter how bad it is, the result is what you want.  We shrank a 5cm tumor to just 3 tiny little dots.  I did 4 treatments of taxol every two weeks after that.  Just put your head down, cry when you need to but keep on walking!!!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo November 2012 michellej1980 IamNancy
